title: Person-specific Behavioral Features for Automatic Stress Detection

author: Jonathan Aigrain, ISIR - Institut des Systèmes Intelligents et de Robotique, Université Pierre et Marie Curie (UPMC)

segmentation: And so I'm Jonathan Egham.
I'm a PhD student at UPMC in Paris and I'm going to present you the behavioral features for automatic stress detection.
So first it is well known and it has been studied for a long time, that understanding nonverbal communication is really important for human human interaction.
It helps us.
And understand the mental state the person we talk with is in and also it allows us to align with this person.
But the one of the main issue with designing machines and systems which are able to understand the signals is that their interpretation is person dependent and context dependent.
So for this work we focus on stressful situations.
And the objective is to automatically detect stress in an unobtrusive way, so using only camera sensors.
By studying the body language mainly.
So before getting into the details of the method, what do we talk about when we say the word stress?
Because there are many definitions and this is the one we use.
It's not the only one, but when I say stress, I refer to that.
So it was definition proposed by Lazarus and there were some conditions regarding the stressor which were added later.
So stress is a result of the other transaction between a person and her environment.

It includes the stressor so the stimuli which is considered as uncontrollable and or unpredictable and there's an evaluation of the situation and the conclusion that this situation is threatening that there might be some harm for the person.
So some coping processes.
Also strategies to try to respond to this stressful demand.
So either by trying to solve the problem or by trying to change your perception of the problem.
And trying to not consider it is a problem anymore.
And several effects on mind and body such as sweating, increased heart rates, swing hard and hopefully some changes on the body language.
So so far stretch diction techniques have been many relying on speech signals and physiological signals, but there are some situations where it might be interesting to look at body language because.
Getting physiological signals is intrusive.
You need to put sensors directly on the person and there are some situations where you cannot do that.
And speech signals is not always available for situations where you're interacting with the machine.
So sometimes body language is the only information you can get.
So, but so far.
To our knowledge, there are only few works that address this problem.
I'm going to review them briefly so Japanese in 2012 showed that behavioral features effectively enhance the performance of stress detection systems, which are based on physiological signals.
So we in RPG series used partial features in a multimodal Fusion model, along with physiological signals an speech signals.
But in this work, in the end, it turns out that possible features were the least effective one.
Left are also in our PhD thesis.
Use visual features to predict intermediate level variables such as gestures, violence, and in general.
And then use this information to predict stress.

I'm going to present our method by following this outline.
So first I'm going to present you the data collection.
Experiment we designed to stress people to get the necessary data.
And then we extracted some features.
I'm going to show you the features we extracted and how we did extract them.
Then I'm going to talk about the person specific normalization problem, because this is a well known issue that when you're working with human emotions.
Two people are not don't express the same emotion the same way, so it might prevent your machine learning algorithm to find an adequate separation.
So you need to try to reduce the impact of these Inter individual differences.
Then I'll present this transaction model with the results obtains and I'll conclude with some perspective and improvements we are working on.

So being watched doing evoluted task can be stressful, so using these results.

And you've got less and less time to answer, and the question gets more and more difficult.
It's performed in front of artist, two people.

It's going to go up at the beginning to make the person feel like she's succeeding and that it is fairly easy.
And then it's going to go down regardless of.
Oh, she's really doing and.
Then making you feel that she's actually not succeeding.
So using this procedure we acquire some data.
So we had 14 participants and for each of the six steps we've got the video of the whole body and a skeleton given by the Kinect and also the video of the face given by an HD camera.
So you can see some example at the bottom and also at the end of the experiment we ask for the self assess stress level from one to five.
So now using this data.

Body features are extracted from the Kinect video and facial features on the HD video.
